'''Marco Beltrami''' (born October 7, 1966) is an American composer of film and television scores. He has worked in a number of genres, including [[Horror film|horror]] (''[[Scream (1996 film)|Scream]]'', ''[[Mimic (film)|Mimic]], [[The Faculty]], [[Resident Evil (film)|Resident Evil]], [[The Woman in Black (2012 film)|The Woman in Black]], [[Carrie (2013 film)|Carrie]], [[A Quiet Place (film)|A Quiet Place]]'', and ''[[The Nun II]]''), [[Action film|action]] (''[[Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines]], [[Live Free or Die Hard]], [[World War Z (film)|World War Z]]''), [[Science fiction film|science fiction]] ([[I, Robot (film)|''I, Robot'']], ''[[Snowpiercer]]''), [[Western (genre)|Western]] (''[[3:10 to Yuma (2007 film)|3:10 to Yuma]], [[Jonah Hex (film)|Jonah Hex]], [[The Homesman]]''), and [[Superhero film|superhero]] (''[[Hellboy (2004 film)|Hellboy]], [[The Wolverine (film)|The Wolverine]], [[Logan (film)|Logan]]'', ''[[Venom: Let There Be Carnage]]'').

A long-time collaborator of [[Wes Craven]], Beltrami scored seven of the director's films including the original four Craven-directed films in the ''[[Scream (franchise)|Scream]]'' franchise (1996â€“2011). He has also worked with such directors as [[James Mangold]], [[Guillermo del Toro]], [[Tommy Lee Jones]], [[Alex Proyas]], [[Ole Bornedal]], [[Kathryn Bigelow]], [[Bong Joon-ho]], [[Dan Gilroy]], and [[John Krasinski]]. He has been nominated for two [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Academy Awards]] for ''[[3:10 to Yuma (2007 film)|3:10 to Yuma]]'' (2007) and ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' (2008), and a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score|Golden Globe Award]] for [[A Quiet Place (film)|''A Quiet Place'']] (2018). He won a [[Satellite Award for Best Original Score|Satellite Award]] for ''[[Soul Surfer (film)|Soul Surfer]]'' (2011) and an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Music Composition for a Documentary Series or Special|Emmy Award]] for ''[[Free Solo]]'' (2018).
